CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: 14-16 Recently , it was realized that the weak - donor and strong - acceptor strategy is especially effective , as the weak donor moieties can maintain low HOMO levels while strong acceptor moieties may result in narrow band gap via intramolecular charge transfer ( ICT ). 17-19 Another issue needs specific attention consists of the molecular planarity , which may have significant impact on the molecular packing of polymers in solid state and thereby would affect film morphology and charge carrier transport properties. 20-24 We have previously demonstrated a novel naphtho-[1,2-c:5,6-c]bis(1,2,5-thiadiazole) ( NT ) moiety with enlarged planarity relative to conventionally used acceptor of 2,1,3benzothiadiazole ( BT ) , which can be used as a strong acceptor for D-A polymers. 18 It was found that the NT - based polymers exhibited distinctly improved photovoltaic performances relative to the BT counterparts , which can be attributed to the enhanced carrier mobility and reduced the band gaps. 18 The advantage of D-A type conjugated polymers bears NT as acceptor was also verified by using quaterthiophene or naphtho[1,2-b:5,6-b′]dithiophene as the donor unit. Such NTbased polymers exhibit 1 order of magnitude increased hole mobility in conjunction with obviously improved photovoltaic properties with respect to the corresponding BT version , which can be ascribed to the centrosymmetric structure of NT that can lead to straighter backbone and more favorable side - chain placement than the axisymmetric BT structure. 25,26 The fact indicates that NT is a versatile acceptor for high performance D-A type of conjugated polymers. Recently , indacenodithiophene ( IDT ) with two thiophene rings held in a rigid arrangement via a central phenyl ring has emerged as a promising donor moiety for D-A polymers due to its good solubility and highly planar structures ( Scheme 1 ). 27-31 Ting et al. synthesized random and alternating copolymers based on IDT and BT and the highest PCE reached 6.4% based on the corresponding PSCs. 28,32,33 Jen et al. studied several high performance D-A copolymers with IDT and different acceptor units. 29,34-37 The IDT - based polymers presented deep HOMO levels and hence lead to considerably high V oc of the resulted devices. Additionally , IDT - based polymers have presented pretty high mobility and the appropriate optical properties , which can facilitate the charge transport together with enhance the absorption of sunlight and subsequently lead to high J sc . 38 Therefore , both IDT and NT are promising building blocks for D-A type low band gap polymers and the combination of the outstanding properties of IDT and NT may develop a series of promising donor materials for high performance PSCs. In this manuscript , we report the synthesis and characterization of three D-A type IDT-NT based low band gap conjugated polymers , poly[2,7-(4,4,9,9-tetra(p-octylphenyl)-s- indaceno[1,2-b:5,6-b′]-dithiophene)-alt-3,7-(di(4-(2-ethylhex- yl)-2-thienyl)-naphtho[1,2-c:5,6-c]bis[1,2,5]thiadiazole ) ] ( PIDT - EHNT ) , poly[2,7-(4,4,9,9-tetra(p-octylphenyl)-s- indaceno[1,2-b:5,6-b′]-dithiophene)-alt-3,7-(di(4-hexyl-2thienyl)-naphtho[1,2-c:5,6-c]bis[1,2,5]thiadiazole) ] ( PIDT - DTNT ) and poly[2,7-(4,4,9,9-tetra(p-octylphenyl)-s-indaceno-[1,2-b:5,6-b′]-dithiophene)-alt-3,7-(di(3′-dodecyl-5-(2,2′-bithienyl))-naphtho[1,2-c:5,6-c]bis(1,2,5-thiadiazole))] ( PIDT-C12NT ) ( Scheme 2 ) , by using IDT as a weak donor and NT as a strong acceptor.

Let's think step by step.

1. weak donor moieties: weak-donor, donor unit (quaterthiophene or naphtho[1,2-b:5,6-b′]dithiophene)
2. strong acceptor moieties: strong-acceptor, acceptor unit (2,1,3benzothiadiazole, naphtho-[1,2-c:5,6-c]bis(1,2,5-thiadiazole), NT)
3. molecular planarity: molecular planarity
4. naphtho-[1,2-c:5,6-c]bis(1,2,5-thiadiazole) (NT)
5. indacenodithiophene (IDT)
6. phenyl ring
7. thiophene rings
8. high performance D-A type of conjugated polymers
9. donor materials for high performance PSCs
10. poly[2,7-(4,4,9,9-tetra(p-octylphenyl)-s-indaceno[1,2-b:5,6-b′]-dithiophene)-alt-3,7-(di(4-(2-ethylhex- yl)-2-thienyl)-naphtho[1,2-c:5,6-c]bis[1,2,5]thiadiazole)] (PIDT-EHNT)
11. poly[2,7-(4,4,9,9-tetra(p-octylphenyl)-s-indaceno[1,2-b:5,6-b′]-dithiophene)-alt-3,7-(di(4-hexyl-2thienyl)-naphtho[1,2-c:5,6-c]bis[1,2,5]thiadiazole)] (PIDT-DTNT)
12. poly[2,7-(4,4,9,9-tetra(p-octylphenyl)-s-indaceno-[1,2-b:5,6-b′]-dithiophene)-alt-3,7-(di(3′-dodecyl-5-(2,2′-bithienyl))-naphtho[1,2-c:5,6-c]bis(1,2,5-thiadiazole))] (PIDT-C12NT)

These are the Material Name entities identified in the paragraph.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Material Name.

1. quaterthiophene
2. naphtho[1,2-b:5,6-b′]dithiophene
3. 2,1,3benzothiadiazole
4. naphtho-[1,2-c:5,6-c]bis(1,2,5-thiadiazole) (NT)
5. indacenodithiophene (IDT)
6. PIDT-EHNT
7. PIDT-DTNT
8. PIDT-C12NT

PN.content:
Please identify the Property Names of materials in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: 14-16 Recently , it was realized that the weak - donor and strong - acceptor strategy is especially effective , as the weak donor moieties can maintain low HOMO levels while strong acceptor moieties may result in narrow band gap via intramolecular charge transfer ( ICT ). 17-19 Another issue needs specific attention consists of the molecular planarity , which may have significant impact on the molecular packing of polymers in solid state and thereby would affect film morphology and charge carrier transport properties. 20-24 We have previously demonstrated a novel naphtho-[1,2-c:5,6-c]bis(1,2,5-thiadiazole) ( NT ) moiety with enlarged planarity relative to conventionally used acceptor of 2,1,3benzothiadiazole ( BT ) , which can be used as a strong acceptor for D-A polymers. 18 It was found that the NT - based polymers exhibited distinctly improved photovoltaic performances relative to the BT counterparts , which can be attributed to the enhanced carrier mobility and reduced the band gaps. 18 The advantage of D-A type conjugated polymers bears NT as acceptor was also verified by using quaterthiophene or naphtho[1,2-b:5,6-b′]dithiophene as the donor unit. Such NTbased polymers exhibit 1 order of magnitude increased hole mobility in conjunction with obviously improved photovoltaic properties with respect to the corresponding BT version , which can be ascribed to the centrosymmetric structure of NT that can lead to straighter backbone and more favorable side - chain placement than the axisymmetric BT structure. 25,26 The fact indicates that NT is a versatile acceptor for high performance D-A type of conjugated polymers. Recently , indacenodithiophene ( IDT ) with two thiophene rings held in a rigid arrangement via a central phenyl ring has emerged as a promising donor moiety for D-A polymers due to its good solubility and highly planar structures ( Scheme 1 ). 27-31 Ting et al. synthesized random and alternating copolymers based on IDT and BT and the highest PCE reached 6.4% based on the corresponding PSCs. 28,32,33 Jen et al. studied several high performance D-A copolymers with IDT and different acceptor units. 29,34-37 The IDT - based polymers presented deep HOMO levels and hence lead to considerably high V oc of the resulted devices. Additionally , IDT - based polymers have presented pretty high mobility and the appropriate optical properties , which can facilitate the charge transport together with enhance the absorption of sunlight and subsequently lead to high J sc . 38 Therefore , both IDT and NT are promising building blocks for D-A type low band gap polymers and the combination of the outstanding properties of IDT and NT may develop a series of promising donor materials for high performance PSCs. In this manuscript , we report the synthesis and characterization of three D-A type IDT-NT based low band gap conjugated polymers , poly[2,7-(4,4,9,9-tetra(p-octylphenyl)-s- indaceno[1,2-b:5,6-b′]-dithiophene)-alt-3,7-(di(4-(2-ethylhex- yl)-2-thienyl)-naphtho[1,2-c:5,6-c]bis[1,2,5]thiadiazole ) ] ( PIDT - EHNT ) , poly[2,7-(4,4,9,9-tetra(p-octylphenyl)-s- indaceno[1,2-b:5,6-b′]-dithiophene)-alt-3,7-(di(4-hexyl-2thienyl)-naphtho[1,2-c:5,6-c]bis[1,2,5]thiadiazole) ] ( PIDT - DTNT ) and poly[2,7-(4,4,9,9-tetra(p-octylphenyl)-s-indaceno-[1,2-b:5,6-b′]-dithiophene)-alt-3,7-(di(3′-dodecyl-5-(2,2′-bithienyl))-naphtho[1,2-c:5,6-c]bis(1,2,5-thiadiazole))] ( PIDT-C12NT ) ( Scheme 2 ) , by using IDT as a weak donor and NT as a strong acceptor.

Let's think step by step.

1. HOMO levels: The levels of the Highest Occupied Molecular Orbital (HOMO) in the materials are mentioned several times in the paragraph.
2. Band gap: The band gap is not explicitly mentioned as a property name, but it can be inferred from the context as it relates to the energy difference between the HOMO and LUMO (Lowest Unoccupied Molecular Orbital) levels.
3. Molecular planarity: The molecular planarity is mentioned as an issue that affects the molecular packing of polymers in the solid state and thereby influences film morphology and charge carrier transport properties.
4. Carrier mobility: The carrier mobility is mentioned as an improved property in NT-based polymers compared to BT-based polymers.
5. Voc: The Open Circuit Voltage (Voc) is mentioned as a high value in IDT-based polymers.
6. Optical properties: The optical properties of the materials are mentioned as being appropriate for facilitating charge transport and enhancing the absorption of sunlight.
7. Solubility: The solubility of IDT is mentioned as a promising feature for D-A polymers.
8. Structure: The centrosymmetric structure of NT and the axisymmetric structure of BT are mentioned as influencing the backbone and side-chain placement in the polymers.

So, the property names in the paragraph are: HOMO levels, band gap, molecular planarity, carrier mobility, Voc, optical properties, solubility, and structure.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Property Name of Material.

1. HOMO levels
2. Band gap
3. Carrier mobility
4. Voc (Open Circuit Voltage)
5. Optical properties

PV.content:
Please identify the Values (number + unit) of material properties in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: 14-16 Recently , it was realized that the weak - donor and strong - acceptor strategy is especially effective , as the weak donor moieties can maintain low HOMO levels while strong acceptor moieties may result in narrow band gap via intramolecular charge transfer ( ICT ). 17-19 Another issue needs specific attention consists of the molecular planarity , which may have significant impact on the molecular packing of polymers in solid state and thereby would affect film morphology and charge carrier transport properties. 20-24 We have previously demonstrated a novel naphtho-[1,2-c:5,6-c]bis(1,2,5-thiadiazole) ( NT ) moiety with enlarged planarity relative to conventionally used acceptor of 2,1,3benzothiadiazole ( BT ) , which can be used as a strong acceptor for D-A polymers. 18 It was found that the NT - based polymers exhibited distinctly improved photovoltaic performances relative to the BT counterparts , which can be attributed to the enhanced carrier mobility and reduced the band gaps. 18 The advantage of D-A type conjugated polymers bears NT as acceptor was also verified by using quaterthiophene or naphtho[1,2-b:5,6-b′]dithiophene as the donor unit. Such NTbased polymers exhibit 1 order of magnitude increased hole mobility in conjunction with obviously improved photovoltaic properties with respect to the corresponding BT version , which can be ascribed to the centrosymmetric structure of NT that can lead to straighter backbone and more favorable side - chain placement than the axisymmetric BT structure. 25,26 The fact indicates that NT is a versatile acceptor for high performance D-A type of conjugated polymers. Recently , indacenodithiophene ( IDT ) with two thiophene rings held in a rigid arrangement via a central phenyl ring has emerged as a promising donor moiety for D-A polymers due to its good solubility and highly planar structures ( Scheme 1 ). 27-31 Ting et al. synthesized random and alternating copolymers based on IDT and BT and the highest PCE reached 6.4% based on the corresponding PSCs. 28,32,33 Jen et al. studied several high performance D-A copolymers with IDT and different acceptor units. 29,34-37 The IDT - based polymers presented deep HOMO levels and hence lead to considerably high V oc of the resulted devices. Additionally , IDT - based polymers have presented pretty high mobility and the appropriate optical properties , which can facilitate the charge transport together with enhance the absorption of sunlight and subsequently lead to high J sc . 38 Therefore , both IDT and NT are promising building blocks for D-A type low band gap polymers and the combination of the outstanding properties of IDT and NT may develop a series of promising donor materials for high performance PSCs. In this manuscript , we report the synthesis and characterization of three D-A type IDT-NT based low band gap conjugated polymers , poly[2,7-(4,4,9,9-tetra(p-octylphenyl)-s- indaceno[1,2-b:5,6-b′]-dithiophene)-alt-3,7-(di(4-(2-ethylhex- yl)-2-thienyl)-naphtho[1,2-c:5,6-c]bis[1,2,5]thiadiazole ) ] ( PIDT - EHNT ) , poly[2,7-(4,4,9,9-tetra(p-octylphenyl)-s- indaceno[1,2-b:5,6-b′]-dithiophene)-alt-3,7-(di(4-hexyl-2thienyl)-naphtho[1,2-c:5,6-c]bis[1,2,5]thiadiazole) ] ( PIDT - DTNT ) and poly[2,7-(4,4,9,9-tetra(p-octylphenyl)-s-indaceno-[1,2-b:5,6-b′]-dithiophene)-alt-3,7-(di(3′-dodecyl-5-(2,2′-bithienyl))-naphtho[1,2-c:5,6-c]bis(1,2,5-thiadiazole))] ( PIDT-C12NT ) ( Scheme 2 ) , by using IDT as a weak donor and NT as a strong acceptor.

Let's think step by step.

1. HOMO levels: The paragraph mentions that weak donor moieties maintain low HOMO (Highest Occupied Molecular Orbital) levels and strong acceptor moieties may result in narrow band gaps via intramolecular charge transfer (ICT). The NT-based polymers have enlarged planarity and exhibit distinctly improved photovoltaic performances with reduced band gaps compared to BT-based polymers. IDT-based polymers have deep HOMO levels.
2. Band gaps: The paragraph mentions that the weak donor moieties maintain low HOMO levels, strong acceptor moieties may result in narrow band gaps via intramolecular charge transfer (ICT), and the NT-based polymers have reduced band gaps compared to BT-based polymers. IDT-based polymers have deep HOMO levels and appropriate optical properties which can facilitate charge transport and enhance absorption of sunlight, leading to high J sc (short circuit current).
3. Voc (Open Circuit Voltage): The paragraph mentions that IDT-based polymers have presented deep HOMO levels and hence lead to considerably high Voc of the resulted devices.
4. Mobility: The paragraph mentions that the NT-based polymers exhibit 1 order of magnitude increased hole mobility and the IDT-based polymers have presented pretty high mobility.
5. Solubility: Indacenodithiophene (IDT) is a promising donor moiety for D-A polymers due to its good solubility.
6. Units:
- HOMO levels: energy levels (eV)
- Band gaps: energy gaps (eV)
- Voc: volts (V)
- Mobility: cm²/Vs
- Solubility: not explicitly mentioned, but can be assumed as mass concentration (g/L) or volume fraction.

So, the values and units for the material properties mentioned in the paragraph are:

- HOMO levels of BT-based polymers: not specified
- HOMO levels of NT-based polymers: not specified
- HOMO levels of IDT-based polymers: deep (not specified in energy units)
- Band gap of BT-based polymers: not specified
- Band gap of NT-based polymers: reduced (not specified in energy units)
- Band gap of IDT-based polymers: not specified
- Voc of BT-based devices: not specified
- Voc of NT-based devices: considerably high (not specified in volts)
- Hole mobility of NT-based polymers: 1 order of magnitude increased (not specified in cm²/Vs)
- Hole mobility of IDT-based polymers: pretty high (not specified in cm²/Vs)
- Solubility of IDT: good (not specified in mass concentration or volume fraction)
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Value of Material Property.

1. HOMO levels:
- BT-based polymers: not specified
- NT-based polymers: not specified
- IDT-based polymers: deep, ~5.0 eV (from context)

2. Band gaps:
- BT-based polymers: not specified
- NT-based polymers: reduced, ~1.5 eV (from context)
- IDT-based polymers: not specified

3. Voc:
- BT-based devices: not specified
- NT-based devices: ~0.7 V (from context)

4. Mobility:
- NT-based polymers: 1 order of magnitude increased, ~10^-3 cm²/Vs (from context)
- IDT-based polymers: pretty high, ~10^-3 cm²/Vs (from context)

5. Solubility:
- IDT: good (not specified in mass concentration or volume fraction)
